qas.question: Do additive or subtractive methods use less raw materials?
What chemical element is often present in the bath used to sensitive exposed film after it's been imaged?
What object is used to expose selected parts of the photosensitive film to light?
In subtractive methods, what metal covers the board and is then partially removed?
In the additive method, which parts of the laminate are plated with copper?

plausible_answers.text: material is needed and less waste is produced

qas.question: The advantage of the subtractive method is that less what?
Bare laminate is placed on top of photosensitive film in what process?
The exposed areas are sensitized using plutonium in what process?
The laminate is plated with silver during what process?
When the PCB is stripped, what is finished?

context: Subtractive methods remove <a3_0>copper<a3_0/> from an entirely copper-coated board to leave only the desired copper pattern. In additive methods the pattern is electroplated onto a bare substrate using a complex process. The advantage of the <a0_0>additive<a0_0/> method is that less <b5_0>material is needed and less waste is produced<b5_0/>. In <b6_0><b7_0><b8_0>the full additive process<b8_0/><b7_0/><b6_0/> the bare laminate is covered with a photosensitive film which is imaged (exposed to light through a <a2_0>mask<a2_0/> and then developed which removes the unexposed film). The exposed areas are sensitized in a chemical bath, usually containing <a1_0>palladium<a1_0/> and similar to that used for through hole plating which makes the exposed area capable of bonding metal ions. The laminate is then plated with copper in the <a4_0>sensitized areas<a4_0/>. When <b9_0>the mask<b9_0/> is stripped, the PCB is finished.
